learningIntentions.text: Define the atom as the smallest unit of matter, define the term element and explain why we have internationally recognised symbols.
Identify how technology has changed our understanding of the structure and properties of elements
Identify some examples of common compounds and distinguish between elements, compounds and mixtures
Describe the properties and uses of some common elements, including metals and non-metals
Investigate how people in different cultures in the past have applied their knowledge of the properties of elements and compounds to their use in everyday life, e.g. utensils, weapons and tools
Identify some observations as evidence of a chemical change
Compare physical and chemical changes in terms of the arrangement of particles and reversibility of the process
Investigate some examples of chemical change that occur in everyday life, e.g. photosynthesis, respiration and chemical weathering
Propose reasons why society should support scientific research, e.g. in the development of new pharmaceuticals and polymers
Describe, using examples, how science knowledge can develop through collaboration and connecting ideas across the disciplines of science, e.g. making or obtaining new substances from Earth's spheres
Extension: Describe molecules of elements, molecules of compounds and lattices
